channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-16285] Drop RPC requests if it must be considered as timeout at client
item.description:
After HBASE-15593, we have a timeout param in header of RPC requests. We can use it in more scenes.
A straightforward scene is to drop requests if it has waited so long in RPC queue and has been dropped by client. Even if we handle this request and send the response back, it will not be used any more. And client may have sent a retry. In an extreme case, if the server is slow, all requests may be timeout or queue-full-exception because we should handle previous requests which have been dropped by client and many resources at server are wasted.
item.summary: Drop RPC requests if it must be considered as timeout at client

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Upload a patch which drops timeout requests at the start of CallRunner.run(). I think it is a simple but useful approach. With this patch we can recover much faster when a RS has been stuck for several seconds.

And there can be more complex improvement which we can do later, for example, aborting a request in the path of reading/writing to reduce the waste of resource.

+1 overall

Upload patch for branch-1 and branch-1.3

Any comments? Thanks

System.currentTimeMillis()
Better use EnvironmentEdgeManager?

dropTimeoutRequestDelay
We need this? Can u explain? The timestamp of call is the time it arrived server and timeout says the client time out value. Why still this small delta? So within the timeout period the server has not processed it but in small delta gap it can be processed and reponded and client sees that? That is very rare no? Just inform client that it is unsuccessful op to server? Even if client was not really timed out and then see as fail. That is ok? We can avoid overhead of one more config!

This message was automatically generated.

Hi Anoop, thanks for your comments.

System.currentTimeMillis()
Better use EnvironmentEdgeManager?

I use System.current because Call.timestamp is also using it in the constructor. Is it ok to change to EnvironmentEdgeManager? Or change both of them?

dropTimeoutRequestDelay

When I use ycsb to benchmark the server, I find that at client the timeout requests don't fail exactly at the time of setting, usually having a delay of several milliseconds because of thread scheduling. If we don't add this delay, the number of failing requests will be a little larger especially when the timeout setting is short, for example, only 50ms. So I think we need this delay. But maybe we need not configurable, we can make it a const. 200ms may be too large, perhaps 50ms is OK for most scenes?

On EnvironmentEdge, see the patch just committed at HBASE-16256. I'd say, it ok to not use EE.

But maybe we need not configurable, we can make it a const. 200ms may be too large, perhaps 50ms is OK for most scenes?

How about no delay padding? (I agree w/ Anoop Sam John that it would be good if we could save on new configs).

On the patch...

96 if (System.currentTimeMillis() >= call.deadline) {

Is it possible that further up in the code, we just did a System.currentTimeMillis (trying to save on our doing too many of them).

This patch is excellent.
It would be great if the rationale behind choosing 200ms or 50ms for DEAFAULT_DROP_TIMEOUT_REQUEST_DELAY is put in the comments for future reference.

Add Call.startTime to save one System.current
Remove dropTimeoutRequestDelay to drop timeout requests immediately

This message was automatically generated.

this.deadline = this.timeout > 0 ? this.timestamp + this.timeout : Long.MAX_VALUE;

deadline is twice the value of timeout? Sorry not following


 Pair<Message, CellScanner> call(BlockingService service, MethodDescriptor md, Message param,

56	      CellScanner cellScanner, long receiveTime, MonitoredRPCHandler status, long startTime,

57	      int timeout) throws IOException, ServiceException;

RpcServerInterface is marked LimitedPrivate and exposed to CP and Phoenix. We need to be careful. There are 2 versions of call() method. I guess the latter is added with BC for old. Why is it like not passing Call object itself then we dont have break signature.

deadline is starttime(timestamp) + timeout, timestamp is set before the call being put into the queue.

I think we can add a new call method whose parameters are Call and MonitoredRPCHandler. All parameters are Call's properties except MonitoredRPCHandler. And we can keep current methods unchanged. Will upload a new patch soon.
Oh my bad eyes. I read timestamp also as timeout.

Drop timeout call:

Dropping timed out call.
May be we can deprecate old call() methods in RpcServerInterface ?

import com.google.protobuf.Descriptors;

Unused?

private Pair<Message, CellScanner> call(BlockingService service, MethodDescriptor md,

The javadoc comes around this private method now move that to actual public methods pls.
Rest looks good

The second call method

Pair<Message, CellScanner> call(BlockingService service, MethodDescriptor md,
Message param, CellScanner cellScanner, long receiveTime, MonitoredRPCHandler status,
int timeout) throws IOException, ServiceException;

is introduced by HBASE-15593 in branch-1.3+. And after adding new method, this one is not used any more, since 1.3.0 is not released, maybe we can remove it and deprecate the first call?
Ping Mikhail Antonov FYI boss.

This message was automatically generated.
All tests are unrelated
Do not set timeout in Call if the timeout in PRC request's header is 0.
Time out of 0 is allowed to be set? What is the meaning? No timeout? So server do not consider client time out when the PB request is not having time out field or timeout is <=0. Correct?

There is no limit if we set timeout to 0. I can not find the correct meaning of zero in docs, so it may depend on the implementation of client? For server I think we should skip setting timeout if the timeout in header is <=0 or there is no timeout in header.
+1. Nice catch BTW. I was thinking 0 wont come in at all and at client end deny it to be set.

-1 overall
